And in August, Leo-people have for their Natal Stone that unusual green gem Peridot, celebrated from Antiquity. (We say Peri-dot! not Peri- doe.) Long before 1500 B.C. it was coming from the Red Sea island of Zebirget. The Romans loved it, favored it as a charm against terror and melancholy. In the Middle Ages it was a talisman against the Evil Eye. In recent times Peridot has been found in meteorites. An interesting gem mineral. Small yellow-green Peridots are not rare; many appear in volcanic rocks in our own Southwest. However, large Peridots of the finest clear olive-green color are scarce. Cut brilliantly, the large ones are so appealing they have been termed evening emerald. Greatly favored in Victorian jewelry, Peridot is coming back.t Fortunately, J'.T., recently globe-trotting in Burma, came upon a find of Peridots of superb quality. I take all! And our Chief Lapidary, with Old Eagle-Eye over his shoulder, has lovingly cut them into brilliant gems. We recommend these highly for unusual rings, and especially, for brooches, necklaces, earrings, and even tie-tacks and cuff-links.
